results.title: The Evil one
results.brief_description: As the hunters return from their hunt, the tribe gathers around the fire to hear stories of the Dreamtime. In this story Marmoo, the Evil one tries to abduct two children and make them his slaves, but after a long chase they are rescued by the Winjarning Brothers, spirits from the heavens, who defeat Marmoo in an epic battle of minds which leaves Marmoo as an ant which then dies. An imaginative recreation of this Aboriginal legend, narrated by Belza Lowah.

results.title: The Evil dead (D)
results.creator_credit: Renaissance, Robert Tapert and Sam Raimi
results.brief_description: The Evil dead emerges as the ultimate in low-budget gore and shock effects. Story premise has five youngsters holed up in a remote cabin where they discover a Book of the Dead. An archaeologists tape recording reveals it having been found among the Khandarian ruins of a Sumerian civilization. Playing the taped incantations unwittingly summons up dormant demons living in the nearby forest, which possesses the youngsters in succession until there is only Ash (Bruce Campbell) left to fight for his survival. While injecting considerable black humour, neophyte Detroit-based writer-director Sam Raimi maintains suspense and a nightmarish mood in between showy outbursts of special effects gore and graphic violence which are staples of modern horror pictures. Powerful camerawork suggests the lurking presence of the huge-scale demons in the forest. Filmed in 1980 at Tennessee and Michigan locations for under $400,000, this is a grainy blowup from 16mm film.

results.title: The Everly Brothers: Album flash
results.creator_credit: Delilah Films, Stephanie Bennett and Richard Deligter
results.brief_description: During the recording of their new album, EB84 in 1984, The Everly Brothers were filmed in their Nashville studios, and in London. This video features in-depth interviews with Don and Phil and their record producer Dave Edmunds. Included are videos for their new songs “You make it seem so easy”, “The story of me”, “Following the sun”, and “On the wings of a nightingale”, penned by such music industry luminaries as Paul McCartney and Jeff Lynne. The result is a fascinating glimpse into the recording life of the Everlys.

results.title: The Ever-changing sky: John Constable 1776-1837
results.brief_description: An appraisal of John Constable, English landscape painter, who lived from 1776 to 1837. Depicts his birthplace and the scenes in Suffolk which inspired many of his paintings. He strove to capture the beauty of nature in his paintings with dramatic and emotional brushwork, and in his freedom and his sense of space and light, he can be seen as the precursor of the plain-air painting of the Impressionists.

results.title: The Ever-changing lowlands
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Joseph Koenig and Tony Ianzelo
results.brief_description: For students of Canadian geography, this film shows the characteristics of the Quebec-Ontario region bordering the United States, where most of Canada’s population settled, and where manufacturing and agriculture thrive.

results.title: The Event of the political party
results.creator_credit: Open University, BBC-TV and Gwynn Pritchard
results.brief_description: One of four films in the “Mass communications and society” series forming a case study on British politics and television, shot during the 1976 Labour and Conservative Party conferences held in Blackpool and Brighton respectively. Concentrates on the live broadcasts of the events of each day and reveals the philosophies that guide the broadcasters in their decision making. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Eternal forest
results.creator_credit: U.S.A Department of Agriculture and United States. Forest Service
results.brief_description: The story of North America’s primeval forests showing early neglect in the years of America’s growth and expansion, as opposed to today’s sensible balance between the use of forest resources and their protection for future generations

results.title: The Eternal forest
results.brief_description: Designed to explain the important part played by forests in paper manufacture. Photographed in the Boola-Boola area of Gippsland, Victoria, various operations are shown in which timber, removed for papermaking, is being replaced by seedling pines which will mature for use in future years. The film includes views of the residential area of Traralgon, the manufacturing processes at the Maryvale mill, and also lists various uses of paper products.

results.title: The Eternal fight
results.creator_credit: Madeleine Carroll Films, United Nations. Film Board, Michael Alexander and Victor Vicas
results.brief_description: Through history humans have fought an eternal struggle against plagues, hunger, and war. Scientists of many nations have contributed to this fight against disease. The developments of the 19th and 20th centuries havce created new health problems because of industrial employment, crowded cities and more rapid means of communication. Control of disease is only now possible on a world-wide basis. The film is a dramatised story of the work of the World Health Organisation organsied to fight disease on a global scale.

results.title: The Esthetics of Disappearance
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
This work, which takes its title from Paul Virilio’s publication of the same name, explores notions of the cinematic in relation to recent global history, with particular focus on the role of the media in conveying information and events into the home via the medium of the television. Virilio’s thesis upon cinema and temporal experience proposed that ‘with the cinematic accelerator…the measure of the world becomes that of the vector of movement, of the means of locomotion that desynchronize time’. Notions of heightened speed and the distortion of perception are conveyed visually in the work by the rapidity of images and their intense colouration.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.
